facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 541 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 541 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1962, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated May 31, 1962 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in S.A.O. No. 86-D of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1962, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in S. A. O. No. 86-D of 1962. S. B. Chari, M. K. Ramamurthi, D. P. Singh and B. K. Garg, for the appellant.

facts.text: Punjab High Court summarily dismissed the appeal filed by the appellant by order dated May 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: judgment and order of a learned single judge of the Punjab High Court summarily dismissing the appeal filed by the appellant, by his order dated May 31, 1962, from the order of the Rent Control Tribunal dated March 7, 1962, confirming that of the Additional Rent Controller, Delhi, dated July 27, 1961

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal confirmed order of Additional Rent Controller dated July 27, 1961 directing eviction of appellant from premises.

anchor.surface_text: from the order of the Rent Control Tribunal dated March 7, 1962, confirming that of the Additional Rent Controller, Delhi, dated July 27, 1961, whereby he had directed the appellant to be evicted from the premises in question.

facts.text: Respondents are landlords of premises No. 24, Ansari Road, Darya Ganj, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the respondents are admittedly the landlords of the premises, No. 24, Ansari Road, Darya Ganj, Delhi. The appellant claims to have been in occupation of the premises since prior to 1950, at a monthly rent of Rs. 50/-

facts.text: Appellant in occupation of premises since prior to 1950 at monthly rent of Rs. 50/-

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claims to have been in occupation of the premises since prior to 1950, at a monthly rent of Rs. 50/-. In 1955, the respondent had instituted a suit for the eviction of the All India Postal R.M.S. Union, and the appellant was also impleaded as a party to the suit.

facts.text: In 1955, respondents instituted suit for eviction of All India Postal R.M.S. Union, appellant impleaded as party.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, the respondent had instituted a suit for the eviction of the All India Postal R.M.S. Union, and the appellant was also impleaded as a party to the suit. The respondents, in 1958, made an application for amendment of the plaint

facts.text: In 1958, respondents applied for amendment of plaint, which was not permitted; permission to withdraw with liberty to file fresh suit granted on May 8, 1959 by Subordinate Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, in 1958, made an application for amendment of the plaint on the ground that they had come to know that the last owner, the father of the first respondent, had let the building to the appellant for his residential purposes and that the case should proceed against him only. But the Subordinate judge, before whom the suit was pending, did not permit the amendment of the plaint but granted permission to withdraw from the suit with liberty to bring a fresh one, by his order dated May 8, 1959.

facts.text: On February 25, 1960, respondents made application before Rent Controller, Delhi for eviction of appellant alone, without impleading the Union.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on February 25, 1960, the respondents made an application before the Rent Controller, Delhi, for the eviction of the appellant alone, without impleading the Union aforesaid as a party The contention of the appellant was that the premises had been let out by the father of the first plaintiff-respondent to the All India Postal R.M.S. Union

facts.text: Appellant contended premises let to All India Postal R.M.S. Union for office-cum-residential purposes, tenancy not terminated; appellant not a tenant but licensee of Union.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant was that the premises had been let out by the father of the first plaintiff-respondent to the All India Postal R.M.S. Union for office-cum- residential purposes and the tenancy of the Union had never been terminated. The appellant also alleged that he was not a tenant and, therefore, the application for his eviction was not maintainable.

facts.text: Eviction petition founded on persistent default in payment of rent by appellant and bona fide requirement for own residence by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The petition for eviction was founded on the allegation that the appellant as tenant had made persistent default in the payment of rent and, secondly, that the premises were bonafide required by the respondents for their own residence, as the first respondent was about to leave the employment of a certain hospital which had provided him with residential accommodation.

facts.text: Appellant denied tenancy, asserted respondents had suitable accommodation, requirement not bona fide, notice of demand invalid as served on non-tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant besides denying his tenancy and asserting the tenancy of the Union aforesaid stated that the respondents had already got suitable accommodation and that their requirement of the premises in question was not bonafide the notice of demand for payment of rent served on the appellant was neither valid not proper in law inasmuch as he was not the tenant in respect of the premises, and that the notice of demand should have been served on the Union.

facts.text: On April 2, 1960, Additional Rent Controller ordered appellant to deposit arrears of rent from August 1, 1958 at Rs. 50/- per month and future rent monthly.

anchor.surface_text: On April 2, 1960, the Additional Rent Controller passed an order directing the appellant to deposit the arrears of rent from August 1,1958, up-to-date, at the rate of Rs. 50/- per month, and future monthly rent, month by month, by the 15th of every following month.

facts.text: On May 16, 1961, respondents applied under s.15(7) of Act to strike out defence due to failure to deposit as directed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents made an application on May 16, 1961, under s. 15(7) of the Act for striking out his defence against eviction on the ground that the tenant had failed to make the payment or deposit, as directed by the order dated April 2, 1960, aforesaid.

facts.text: Appellant denied default or asserted it was unintentional due to miscalculation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied that he had made any default in the regular payment of rent, but also asserted that if there was any such default it was not intentional and was the result of a miscalculation.

facts.text: On July 26, 1961, Additional Rent Controller struck out appellant's defence.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated July 26, 1961, the Additional Rent Controller ordered the defence of the appellant to be struck out.

facts.text: Appeal against striking out defence filed to Rent Control Tribunal on September 15, 1961, late by one day; dismissed as time-barred and on merits on March 6, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against the order striking out his defence was made to the Rent Control Tribunal on September 15, 1961, which was late by one day. The learned Tribunal dismissed the appeal as time-barred, as also on merits, by its order dated March 6, 1962.

facts.text: On July 17, 1961, Additional Rent Controller passed ex-parte ejectment order against appellant, holding prima facie landlord-tenant relationship and bona fide need established based on rent receipts.

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated July 17 , 1961, the Additional Rent Controller passed an ex-parte order of,ejectment against the appellant holding that prima facie the relationship of landlord and tenant had been established, on the basis of certain rent receipts granted by the respondents to the appellant.

facts.text: Rent Control Tribunal dismissed appeal against ejectment order on March 7, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal against that order was dismissed on March 7, 1962, by the Rent Control Tribunal.

facts.text: Second appeal filed in Punjab High Court on May 28, 1962 against Tribunal's March 7, 1962 order; dismissed summarily on May 31, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On May 28, 1962, the appellant filed a second appeal in the High Court of Punjab at Delhi against the order dated March .7, 1962, of the Rent Control Tribunal, dismissing his appeal against the order of eviction. ... The second appeal was dismissed summarily by a Single judge on May 31, 1962.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted by Vacation Judge on June 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved this Court during the long vacation and obtained an order from the learned Vacation judge granting special leave to appeal, on June 5, 1962.

facts.text: No second appeal filed against Tribunal's March 6, 1962 order striking out defence, making it final.

anchor.surface_text: No second appeal was taken to the High Court in respect of the dismissal of the appeal relating to the order dated March 6, 1962, of the Rent Control Tribunal dismissing his appeal in respect of the order of the Additional Rent Controller striking out his defence.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction as appellant participated in proceedings under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller, therefore, must be taken to have decided that there was a relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties, and secondly, that the tenant was entitled to the protection under the Act.

facts.text: Court found no merit in appeal challenging jurisdiction due to denial of tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, there is no substance in the contention that as soon as the appellant denied the relationship of landlord and tenant the jurisdiction of the authorities under the Act was completely ousted.

issues.text: whether or not the Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction in the matter in controversy in this case

anchor.surface_text: The most important question that arises for determination in this case is whether or number the Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction in the matter in- companytroversy in this case.

issues.text: whether the authorities under the Act had jurisdiction to entertain the proceedings, inasmuch as it was denied that there was any relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that the authorities under the Act had numberjurisdiction to entertain the proceedings, inasmuch as it was denied that there was any relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties. Consequently, it was further companytended,

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, it was further companytended, the provisions of s. 15  7  of the Act companyld number be applied against the appellant in the absence of a finding that he was the tenant in respect of the premises in question.

arguments.claim: Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction to determine landlord-tenant relationship despite denial

anchor.surface_text: The most important question that arises for determination in this case is whether or number the Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction in the matter in- companytroversy in this case. Ordinarily it is for the Civil Courts to determine whether and, if so, what jural relationship exists between the litigating parties. But the Act has been enacted

arguments.claim: Controller authorised under s.15(4) to decide who entitled to rent, implying jurisdiction over relationship

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 15  4  of the Act, the Controller is authorised to decide the question whether the claimant was entitled to an order for payment of rent, and if there is a dispute as to the person or persons to whom the rent is payable, he may direct the tenant

arguments.claim: Order under s.15(1) and s.15(7) assumes decision on landlord-tenant relationship

anchor.surface_text: The Controller, therefore, must be taken to have decided that there was a relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties, and secondly, that the tenant was entitled to the protection under the Act.

arguments.claim: Appellant by participating and seeking s.15 orders invoked jurisdiction and cannot deny it

anchor.surface_text: If the appellant took his stand upon the plea that he was number a tenant he should have simply denied the relationship and walked out of the proceedings. Instead of that, he took active steps to get the protection against eviction afforded by Act

arguments.claim: Simple denial of relationship does not oust jurisdiction of limited but exclusive tribunals under Act

anchor.surface_text: True, they are tribunals of the limited jurisdiction, the scope of their power and authority being limited by the provisions of the Statute. But within the provisions of the Act, they are tribunals of exclusive jurisdiction and their orders are final

arguments.claim: s.15 provisions primarily for tenant's benefit; appellant invited orders

anchor.surface_text: Now, proceedings under s. 15 are primarily meant for the benefit of the tenant, and the section authorises the Controller after giving the parties an opportunity of being heard, to make an order directing the tenant to pay the amount found on calculation

arguments.claim: Controller's decision on relationship not res judicata in civil suit but final within Act

anchor.surface_text: Such a decision may number be res judicata in a regular suit in which a similar issue may directly arise for decision. Hence, any orders made by a Controller under the Act proceed on the assumption that he has the necessary power

arguments.claim: No merit in appeal challenging jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, there is numbersubstance in the companytention that as soon as the appellant denied the relationship of landlord and tenant the jurisdiction of the authorities under the Act was companypletely ousted. Nor is there any jurisdiction in the companytention

holdings.text: Rent Control authorities had jurisdiction to entertain the eviction proceedings and determine the landlord-tenant relationship despite denial by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: True, they are tribunals of the limited jurisdiction, the scope of their power and authority being limited by the provisions of the Statute. But within the provisions of the Act, they are tribunals of exclusive jurisdiction and their orders are final

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory tribunals under the Act must decide threshold issues like tenancy as part of their limited but exclusive jurisdiction; simple denial does not oust jurisdiction; appellant's participation invokes it.

holdings.text: The orders passed under Sections 15(1) and 15(7) of the Act imply that the Controller decided there was a landlord-tenant relationship and the appellant was entitled to protection under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Controller, therefore, must be taken to have decided that there was a relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties, and secondly, that the tenant was entitled to the protection under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions of s.15 assume jurisdiction over tenancy; orders for deposit and striking defence passed after hearing parties, primarily for tenant's benefit.

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention that denial of landlord-tenant relationship ousted the jurisdiction of the authorities under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, there is no substance in the contention that as soon as the appellant denied the relationship of landlord and tenant the jurisdiction of the authorities under the Act was completely ousted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Participation in proceedings and seeking benefits under s.15 invokes jurisdiction; simple denial insufficient to block proceedings.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.15(7) were correctly applied; no substance in contention of erroneous application absent explicit tenancy finding.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there any substance in the contention that the provisions of sub-s. 7 of s. 15 of the Act had been erroneously applied to the appellant. The orders under those provisions were for his benefit

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.15 orders invited by appellant for his benefit; assumes tenancy; failure to comply leads to striking defence.

holdings.text: Order of Rent Control Tribunal dated March 6, 1962, dismissing appeal against striking out defence became final as no second appeal filed, barring challenge to jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The position is that the appellate order of the Rent Control Tribunal, dated March 6, 1962, dismissing the appeal against the order striking out his defence became final between the parties and is no more open to challenge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No second appeal against striking defence order makes it final; cannot collaterally challenge in eviction appeal.

holdings.text: Refusal to condone one-day delay in appeal to Rent Control Tribunal was within discretion of appellate authority; no interference warranted.

anchor.surface_text: Whether or not a delay of one day should have been condoned was a matter of discretion with the appellate authority, and it is not for this Court to say that this discretion should have been exercised

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion based on sufficient cause; appeal dismissed on merits too; no erroneous considerations shown.

holdings.text: There is no merit in the appeal.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction upheld; procedural orders final; no grounds to interfere with eviction.
